messages: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:31): It's not self evident?

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:33): I don't think that's the only criterion

1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (17:17): 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132: congrats :)
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (17:17): thanks 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (17:18): that reminds me I have some sites to submit too
73cc301f328d92a18944f8e1a0d91e72 (17:20): does mime a/x+x always force standard mode?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:21): 73cc301f328d92a18944f8e1a0d91e72: Yes, quirks mode exists only for text/html content
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (17:21): This brought up an interesting question though, how do you organize preview content.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (17:22): What if you show part of an article that takes you to its own page, is that preview "intended to be independently distributable or reusable"?
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (17:22): If not, what is it, is it part of the outline?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:24): I would use <section> YMMV
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (17:24): You Make Me Vomit?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:24): Well that too
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (17:24): Your Milage May Vary?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:25): I guess we should go with the latter on the basis of public hygine
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:26): We need namespaces for acronyms.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:26): s/acronyms/abbrevations/
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (17:26): :) yea I could see how they could belong to a section.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (17:26): It's a section containing links to other sections and articles.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (17:26): I s'pose.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:32): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I suggest a namespacing syntax in which you put disambiguating lowercase letters after each of the acronym's letters
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:34): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: That doesn't appear to involve URIs and therefore doesn't allow for Distributed Extensibility

abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (17:47): Can I just quickly check with you guys that I'm understanding the script element correctly: if you're linking off to a file using the src attribute, you don't need to use the type attribute but if you are putting code between the opening and closing script tags insetad, you *must* use the type attribute?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:48): No, that's wrong
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:48): You never need the type attribute
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:48): Except if the script isn't JS

abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (17:49): This bit of the spec: "When used to include data blocks, the data must be embedded inline, the format of the data must be given using the type attribute, and the src attribute must not be specified." makes it sound like type is mandatory when not using src.
abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (17:50): http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/scripting-1.html#script
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (17:50): The sentence before it explicitly says it isn't
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:50): "When used to include data blocks"
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:50): JavaScript isn't data blocks.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:51): I was never sure what that section of the spec was meant to refer to.
abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (17:51): The sentence before it refers only to scripts referenced with the src attribute, not inline scripts.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:51): Some hypothetical usage, or do people actually do that?

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:51): "When used to include dynamic scripts, the scripts may either be embedded inline or may be imported from an external file using the src attribute. If the language is not that described by "text/javascript", then the type attribute must be present, as described below."
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:51): That covers all usage of JavaScript, since you're including dynamic scripts, not data blocks.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (17:51): abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4: "either embedded inline or..."

abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (17:52): Sounds like the sentence that's confusing me could be clarified by adding the words "non-JavaScript" i.e.: "When used to include non-JavaScript data blocks..."
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:53): I think the intent is that all data blocks are non-JavaScript, but it's sort of vague about what "data blocks" means.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:53): I don't know why the distinction is drawn.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:53): I suggest you file a bug or post to whatwg.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (17:53): Data is not code
abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (17:53): I'll post a comment.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:53): Sum Ruby might disagree
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:54): abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4, that's the same as filing a bug.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:54): The sum of all rubies?
abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (17:54): comment/bug posted/filed
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:55): Data blocks are things like <script type="text/glsl-vs">here's some text that other scripts can extract, and it can say x < y etc safely</script>
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:56): You could do something like put JSON data in there too
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:56): or even put JS code which should be accessible to the rest of the page and should not be executed
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:56): though then you'd have to come up with a new content-type for it
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (17:57): text/not-javascript-I-promise
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:57): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: XML is not great because it might include the string "</script>" and you can't escape that at all
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:58): but I think some people use it for that anyway
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:58): JSON might also include the string "</script>".
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:59): You can write "<\/script>" then
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:00): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Presumably you can escape the XML
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:00): Then it wouldn't be XML
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:00): It'd be XML in some wrapper format
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:01): Yes, if you're being pedantic
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:02): (although strictly I don't know if you can embed XML in some other format and call it XML anyway._
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:03): Random thought: how long until browser JITs implement speculative execution and branch prediction so they can use multiple cores for single-threaded JS?  :)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:06): I imagine the synchronisation overhead would make that kind of fine-grained concurrency impossible
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:07): What if you did it while the script was blocked on something, like a network read?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:08): The script is almost certainly going to use the read data almost immediately
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:08): so you couldn't speculate ahead very far
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:08): What if it's a long-running app like Gmail and you can guess the read data?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:09): And there are relatively few cases where you are blocked on network
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:09): If you're blocked on the network then your performance is terribly anyway
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:09): and nobody's going to notice a few extra milliseconds

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:09): just realized that once IE9 is released, he should update his website to use inline SVG-in-HTML someplace, so that his site is once again so standard that it no longer works interoperably.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:10): It will be awesomely ironic if my site is so standards-compliant that it only works properly in IE.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:10): Actually, it wouldn't work properly in any browser, since IE won't support CSS gradients (probably).  Even better.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:10): I suppose they could do more things as background optimisations, like guess parameters for functions that haven't been called yet and call them in a separate thread in order to get traces and statistics for the JIT
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:11): though the actual execution of code would still be single-threaded
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:11): realizes he doesn't really know anything about SVG, and should read the spec.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:11): What spec should I start with?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:11): I suggest the SVG spec
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:11): There are multiple SVG specs, as far as my understanding goes.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:11): Like multiple versions?  Profiles?  That kind of thing?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:12): I believe http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/ is what most browsers target

70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:12): A Question about HTML5 outlines for those interested in particulars: I have a collection of blog previews, like 10 titles each with the first paragraph and a "click to read more" link.  Are each of these previews an article, or do they all belong to one article/ section and have no individual outlining weight of their own?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:20): An IE person responded here, but ignored questions asking about <canvas>: http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2010/03/18/svg-in-ie9-roadmap.aspx
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:20): I'm guessing they haven't fully decided whether they'll do <canvas> yet or not.
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (18:24): you saw the amd press release that hinted at it, yes?
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (18:24): http://blogs.amd.com/developer/2010/03/16/ie9-takes-advantage-of-the-gpu/ " The <canvas> element will be accelerated on the GPU via Direct2D and...."
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:25): Interesting.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:25): I wonder if AMD knows what it's talking about.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:25): That looks like a blog post, not a press release.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:26): "The information presented in this document is for informational purposes only and may contain technical inaccuracies, omissions and typographical errors. Links to third party sites are for convenience only, and no endorsement is implied."
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:26): Google isn't clear on whether Robin Maffeo works for Microsoft or AMD.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:32): Any responses / opinions about article previews?
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:33): I'm hoping this question clears up future decisions I make about how to organize my content.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:47): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Or they've decided but don't want to announce it quite yet
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:48): Maybe they don't want to announce plans for anything they haven't implemented, in case they have to scrap it.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:48): Need some extra features to keep people interested in future releases
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:48): I expect that if they knew for sure they wouldn't implement it, they'd probably say so.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:48): They've said that for other things, like Acid3.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:49): They've announced <video> but not shipped it in the preview build
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:49): so the current version is definitely not the complete set of features

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:51): They'd probably never say no to anything, but they'd probably do what they did before IE8 and avoid the quesion by just saying they're going to implement things based on customer demand
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:52): instead of the current approach of avoiding the question by not responding to it or (if they can't avoid it that way) saying to wait and see
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:53): They demoed <video>.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:54): (It's fun trying to reach conclusions based on non-information, even if it's not a very accurate method)

abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (19:03): I believe the plan is for Microsoft to release updates to the developer preview of IE9 at regular intervals. I suspect each release will include more updates.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:05): I'd assume that they wouldn't make a new release with no updates.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:05): It's every eight weeks, by the way.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:07): Roughly every eight
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:11): (... i.e. they're not committing to a fixed schedule in the style of other browsers' nightly builds)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:12): (Not that that makes much difference, as long as you're not marking the dates on your calendar in advance)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:22): You mean you're not?  :(
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:23): I don't have a calendar

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:26): "For years, Viacom continuously and secretly uploaded its content to YouTube, even while publicly complaining about its presence there. It hired no fewer than 18 different marketing agencies to upload its content to the site. It deliberately "roughed up" the videos to make them look stolen or leaked. It opened YouTube accounts using phony email addresses. It even sent employees to Kinko's to upload clips from computers that couldn't be traced

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:26): to Viacom. And in an effort to promote its own shows, as a matter of company policy Viacom routinely left up clips from shows that had been uploaded to YouTube by ordinary users. Executives as high up as the president of Comedy Central and the head of MTV Networks felt "very strongly" that clips from shows like The Daily Show and The Colbert Report should remain on YouTube." http://youtube-global.blogspot.com/2010/03/broadcast-yourself.html
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:26): Of course, it was posted by a lawyer and relates to an ongoing legal case, so possibly it's all lies, but still.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:47): Is there a standards-compliant way to tell whether a page has already finished loading from JavaScript, if the script might be executed after the load event has fired (e.g., from a bookmarklet)?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:57): I mean a standards-compliant way that's not completely hackish, needless to say.
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (19:57): document.readyState though it doesnt have great support.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:58): (apropos: http://tech.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=1588514&cid=31536576)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:05): Oh well, I guess he was right then.
